caseTitle: EBUSUAPANIN KOFI ASIEDU v. EBUSUAPANIN KWEKU APPIAH,
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana upheld the plaintiff's paramount or allodial title to the land known as MPREBUA in Breman Asikuma, affirming that the defendant's land (ABINA) was part of the plaintiff's larger parcel. While the Court of Appeal had granted the defendant usufructuary rights over portions he occupied, the Supreme Court found this determination unsatisfactory due to lack of clear findings on specific occupied areas and duration. The court dismissed the appeal on title but remitted the case to the trial court for fresh evidence to properly delineate areas of occupation and determine valid usufructuary interests. The Supreme Court also declined to uphold estoppel based on a 1980 settlement document (Exhibit 'A'), emphasizing the need for probative evidence on recent possession. No damages or injunction were ultimately awarded.
verdict: Appeal dismissed on title; case remitted for fresh evidence on occupation
rationaleHighlights: Plaintiff proved superior title through traditional and boundary evidence
Defendant's land ABINA was part of plaintiff's MPREBUA land
Recent acts of possession favored plaintiff
Exhibit 'A' (1980 settlement) lacked probative value for estoppel
No clear findings on occupied areas necessitated remittal
Usufructuary title granted by lower court deemed unsatisfactory
Fresh evidence required to identify valid occupations
Injunction and damages claims failed due to insufficient proof
